fields.tagline: "What the hell am I doing here?"
fields.summary: Wherein I try to explain/justify the countless hours I've poured into getting this personal website off the ground. Includes a short description of the journey and technology behind it, and describes the expectations I've set for myself at this very early stage.
fields.content:
[{"id": "4eaf4b81-ac26-4ca8-9e51-d2624c9bc4ac", "type": "rich_text", "value": "

Actually I decided to start a blog sometime late in the 20th century. And here it is! First I spend 2.5 decades as a web developer, working out what I need to know, and then finally found the time. This whole dammed \"web\" thing kept evolving and moving the goal posts, ya know?

Why am I here?

Many reasons.

  • I'm always learning new things, and spending all my time split between official documentation, books, ChatGPT, and StackOverflow, because there are no good tutorials or guides anywhere on the internet (that I can find), and I'm driven to close those gaps
  • Having your very own web presence felt like a cool idea to me in 1997, and I never lost that feeling. Skip to today, with centralised social media hastening the downfall of civilisation, it's not just cool it's literally revolutionary!
  • To earn a modicum of credibility as a developer/person/potential employee \u2013 and especially to feel confident calling myself a \"full stack\" developer \u2013 writing a front-end, a back-end, a DevOps pipeline, running it all in production yourself feels good
  • Now I have one repository that's also a rapid-development platform, which I can keep up-to-date with tooling, where I can experiment with whatever I want while not having to worry about bootstrapping new projects all the time\u00a0\u2013\u00a0\"feature\" branches, ftw!

What do I plan to write about?

Mostly I'm planning on writing up technical guides, recipes, tutorials, and what-have-yous, just based on whatever I've been learning or working with lately \u2013 but only when there isn't already a wealth of Googleable stuff out there already.

But this is my blog, and I'll be dammed if I'm going to hold myself back from the temptation to opine about whatever's going on in the world or my life. Maybe reviews of books and movies? I just like writing! You won't find a skerrick of \"AI generated\" content here.

What is it made of?

I took the best damn CMS framework in the world (Wagtail), written on top of the best dammed web framework in the world (Django), and wrote a CMS & blog application generic enough that I eventually split it out into a package called Picata. The goal is to develop Picata into a CMS solution others might find useful, since as wonderful as Wagtail is it does require weeks-to-months of full-stack developer time to turn it into a nice and working website, the the offerings for pre-built solutions are currently scarce.

You'll find more details between the Picata docs and the repo for this site itself.

I learned a lot of interesting modern stuff along the way, but TailwindCSS deserves a special mention for all the front-end styling you see before you; I found it utterly game-changing when it comes to rapidly generating pretty, concise, responsive CSS. It even made it easy to write themes you can change between (with those buttons in the top-right corner), and I could still do it all in Sass! (Mmmm, semantic whitespace.)

Epilogue

I'm not exactly a heavy user of all the social sites linked to in the footer, but it seemed wise to reference my official accounts on my own website, as a guard against identity theft, and to help the SEO bots know who I am.

Anyway, I hope you enjoy my stuff!

"}]

fields.tagline: Just is a beautiful solution to the problems lurking within the fraught problem-realm known to computer scientists as "running stuff"
fields.summary: Just is basically a command-runner. After decades of using other standard (but in retrospect ad-hoc methods), I've settled comfortably into writing just one Justfile, at the root of any given project, for the vast majority of "shell-scripty" stuff (aka the glue) required to get anything useful done.
fields.content:
[{"id": "cb48d52a-4faf-4e72-8c66-a44a91f1d564", "type": "rich_text", "value": "

Just is basically a command-runner, and a great blessing in my life. What have I done to \"just run commands\" in the past? I took a relatively standard-looking journey through the problem of \"running stuff\", which vaguely went:

  • Excessive use of man pages to remember arguments and flags
  • Abusive grepping of a shell's history to see what I'd done before
  • A Constant addition of aliases and functions to my shell via startup files
  • Pipenv [scripts], npm \"scripts\", other and other tool-spcific stuff
  • Make? CMake?!
  • Maybe just a bunch of .sh files under a scripts/ directory?
"}]

fields.tagline: How I learned to stop worrying and love `repo: local`
fields.summary: The pre-commit package is a great way to quickly get a repo running with lots of pre-commit checks you shouldn't have to spend time coding into hooks yourself. But it uses virtual environments behind the scenes in an opaque way that comes with a caveat you should be mindful of.
fields.content:
[{"id": "d5d4814d-5e7c-4898-a957-4d2d2b4570bb", "type": "rich_text", "value": "

The pre-commit package is a great way to quickly get a repo running with lots of checks you might not have even thought about, and shouldn't have to spend time manually coding into hooks yourself. It's certainly helping keep my projects extra-squeaky-clean in a way that feeds back to my brain in the form of lots of little dopamine hits.

Check out the .pre-commit-config.yaml file behind this site's codebase to see what I'm actually using on it today.

My initial concern, though, was that pre-commit install does of course take over the pre-commit hooks for a repository, because it relies on its own .git/hooks/pre-commit executable script – and it wasn't immediately obvious how I could just add my own arbitrary checks.

TL;DR?

"Repository local hooks" are your friend.

"}, {"id": "82f192b3-96e5-4884-8dcd-c924fede42f3", "type": "rich_text", "value": "

Invisible virtual environments

One slightly magical, opaque implementation detail about pre-commit is that every hook basically creates and runs in its own virtual environment. What that looks like depends on the "language" associated with the hook itself, and there are a couple of notable exceptions:

  • "script" hooks, for simple scripts used to validate files,
  • "system" hooks, which target system-level executables, and
  • Repository-local hooks, most useful when the hook itself depends on build artefacts in your project, or fairly "complete" virtual environments that you don't want to re-build just for that hook.

Additional dependencies

If a hook isn't working the way you'd expect, it may be due to the fact that the virtual environment its creating for itself doesn't have quite everything it needs to run – this is where the additional_dependencies lists come into your configuration. Most hook repositories seem pretty good about mentioning the kind of things you'll need to add here – for example I got my eslint hook running with just:

"}, {"id": "a56202e8-ddf7-4818-8f07-5bbfe8296190", "type": "code", "value": {"code": "- repo: https://github.com/pre-commit/mirrors-eslint rev: "v9.18.0" hooks: - id: eslint name: Lint ECMAScript with eslint args: ["--config", "./eslint.config.mjs"] additional_dependencies: - eslint@9.16.0 - eslint-plugin-prettier@5.2.1 - eslint-plugin-tailwindcss@3.17.5 - eslint-plugin-react@7.37.2 - typescript-eslint@8.17.0", "language": "yaml"}}, {"id": "ef2f1470-5df1-4ed2-a772-ac4d5e0e25cf", "type": "rich_text", "value": "

Static typing, and just using 'local'

It was only after spending some time trying to get mypy for pre-commit working that the penny really dropped for me, with regard to how much of a working virtualenv some things actually need. Calling mypy . was finally going smoothly, with no more configuration required than what was in my pyproject.toml:

"}, {"id": "928d2402-6b63-4711-a7e4-d1c142548849", "type": "code", "value": {"code": "[tool.mypy] exclude = [ '^(.git|.pytest_cache|.ruff_cache|.venv)/.*', '^(build|dist|infra|lib|logs|media|node_modules|snapshots|static)/.*', ] mypy_path = "$MYPY_CONFIG_FILE_DIR/src" plugins = ["mypy_django_plugin.main"] ignore_missing_imports = true [tool.django-stubs] django_settings_module = "picata.settings.mypy"", "language": "toml"}}, {"id": "7ad59cae-8632-4881-b5d8-e73e294ed238", "type": "rich_text", "value": "

… but the mypy pre-commit hook was complaining about one more required dependency after another, until I realise I realised I was about to completely re-create pretty much my entire Python virtual environment, invisibly, in the background, just for this hook to run.

And it's not like mypy was going to change anything, so the principle of isolating pre-commit hooks in their own virtual environments for safety (or whatever) reasons seemed moot. Surely there had to be a better way?

The better way

As you might have guessed by now, the better way came in the form of abandoning the mypy pre-commit hook package completely, just using repo: local, and telling pre-commit what it was I wanted it to run against my already-built virtual environment:

"}, {"id": "e2829a7f-fcb4-445d-84a4-5d2f0a082f2d", "type": "code", "value": {"code": "- repo: local hooks: - id: mypy name: Type-check Python with mypy language: python types: [python] entry: mypy args: ["--config-file=pyproject.toml"]", "language": "yaml"}}, {"id": "9810f7db-f8d5-49cb-9e85-6a6ce1955e6b", "type": "rich_text", "value": "

So, yeah. For many pre-commit checks, it might be easier to not go looking for a third-party repository, and just call what you want, when you want, how you want.

"}, {"id": "b5fa2420-a43c-445a-8706-7c3269a91772", "type": "code", "value": {"code": "❯ pre-commit run mypy --all-files Type-check Python with mypy..............Passed", "language": "bash"}}]

fields.tagline: "Import only what you need to survive"
fields.summary: Development server running out of memory? Or maybe your runserver process is taking forever to load, and other management commands take too long? Here are some optimisation tips I used to speed up – and slim down – every part of my Django development experience.
fields.content:
[{"id": "5462860b-3278-4e40-bdc0-4d8a2d16d5ea", "type": "rich_text", "value": "

The basics

Your Django settings are conceptually fairly simple, and should be kept simple in practice. For most purposes it's generally best to just start with three modules under your (project).settings package…

  • base.py for the vast majority of defaults not affected by the environment
  • dev.py, importing everything from base.py and adding dev/debug settings
  • prod.py, importing everything from base.py and adding production settings

I'd also go so far as to argue that your concrete settings files are literally the only place in a codebase where it's acceptable to just "import star", though hopefully you're using Ruff or a similar linter, and at least acknowledge the potential folly with an ignore directive…

"}, {"id": "956e470b-4eb4-4f34-9839-d38f1d7047b4", "type": "code", "value": {"code": "from .base import * # noqa: F403", "language": "python"}}, {"id": "bc7bb96e-766e-4f2d-bfd2-5503f05e2ce6", "type": "rich_text", "value": "

Something fishy going on

Some time into development, after naïvely adding a lot of "dev-mode-and-debugging" stuff to my dev.py, I noticed a few of things:

  • My dev servers (which were DigitalOcean droplets with 2cpus & 8 gigs of ram at the time) were running out of memory a lot more often than they should
  • runserver_pluswas taking ages to start serving pages
  • django-admin commands were taking unusually long to run
  • mypy was taking yonks to do its thing, and mypyd was the main process eating up all of my precious memory
"}, {"id": "1a850079-9156-4e4b-8ec7-46a75d51feb1", "type": "rich_text", "value": "

The diagnosis

So yes, the thing is, if your "dev settings" just turn everything on at the module level then all those things are going to be imported and run whenever any Django management command runs.

If you've moved at all beyond the basics, that might mean you're loading django-extensions and the Django Debug Toolbar into your code with every command, and if you've stepped into the wonderful world of static type-checking you might be letting django-stubs monkey-patch your code. (Or at least I was…)

But: I found I don't actually need django-extensions for anything at all besides runserver(_plus), and monkey-patching type-hints into Django is resource intensive, and only needed for mypy[d].

"}, {"id": "67e42a76-b7d9-4831-bbbc-3ba28829d167", "type": "rich_text", "value": "

The solutions

Conditional settings & discovering the execution context

Django doesn't provide an immediately obvious way for you to tell exactly what spawned the code that's currently being imported…

Your manage.py is a simple little file that generally remains untouched, and acts as the entry-point for the django-admin command (assuming you aren't already just running things with python manage.py) – but people can and do often augment it for their own purposes and this is an ideal time to add a couple of lines before that final execute_from_command_line(argv) call:

"}, {"id": "eefff5a9-072d-4441-97b7-b1539a202111", "type": "code", "value": {"code": "if len(argv) >= 2: # noqa: PLR2004 environ.setdefault("DJANGO_MANAGEMENT_COMMAND", argv[1]) from django.core.management import execute_from_command_line execute_from_command_line(argv)", "language": "python"}}, {"id": "a5c6cf0d-2bf2-4a29-ae68-f066f94c5435", "type": "rich_text", "value": "

And now you can selectively and exclusively import django-extensions and all the DJDT stuff when you know you're in a runserver or runserver_plus context with something like like this in your (project).settings.dev module:

"}, {"id": "7240bf41-70ec-479d-9b25-85b556113571", "type": "code", "value": {"code": "if getenv("DJANGO_MANAGEMENT_COMMAND", "").startswith("runserver"): RUNSERVERPLUS_POLLER_RELOADER_TYPE = "watchdog" RUNSERVER_PLUS_EXCLUDE_PATTERNS = [ ".venv/*", ".vscode/*", "node_modules/*", "media/*", "src/migrations/*", "static/*", ] # Enable Django Debug Toolbar and runserver_plus INSTALLED_APPS += [ "debug_toolbar", "django_extensions", ] MIDDLEWARE = ["debug_toolbar.middleware.DebugToolbarMiddleware", *MIDDLEWARE]", "language": "python"}}, {"id": "95e5f16f-08ba-4c17-9a22-74dd47e8aaa9", "type": "rich_text", "value": "

(and yes there are a few hints for other optimisations you should consider if you haven't already, embedded in that block of code.)

"}, {"id": "fc562879-e5f4-4ba1-8652-15318e91b3d8", "type": "rich_text", "value": "

Settings exclusive to mypy (or whatever the kids are typing-checking with these days)

This brings us to the "in 4 parts" bit of this post. I now have a forth settings module in the form of mypy.py which consists entirely of:

"}, {"id": "f9d368d0-1254-4ba7-ba13-24d63bc9a7cd", "type": "code", "value": {"code": """"Django settings for the mypy type-checking daemon.""" import django_stubs_ext from .dev import * # noqa: F403 django_stubs_ext.monkeypatch()", "language": "python"}}, {"id": "856e31fe-697d-4b07-a4fd-8da214c55ff4", "type": "rich_text", "value": "

… and then we can ensure the heavy burden of monkey-patching Django with type-hinting stubs happens when (and only when) needed by adding adding to our pyproject.toml:

"}, {"id": "2efa12b4-15bf-4775-b331-1ef58b13dee1", "type": "code", "value": {"code": "[tool.django-stubs] django_settings_module = "(project).settings.mypy"", "language": "toml"}}, {"id": "7e354794-1415-4e6e-b049-79ffaac523a8", "type": "rich_text", "value": "

– that means:

  1. any mypyd processes VS Code might launch if you've got an extension like matangover.mypy installed, and
  2. the mypy process itself, which is great to run as a pre-commit hook.
"}, {"id": "8ebf1316-b2c0-4e01-9c3d-96b6e017c8c4", "type": "rich_text", "value": "

The result…

  • runserver[_plus] need not waste your resources on loading Django stubs
  • mypy[d] won't be wasting cycles & memory on debug stuff meant only for you
  • All the other Django management commands aren't bogged down by your debugging code or monkey-patched type-hints

… and you can be happier, and iterate faster, on smaller development boxes. And isn't that what it's really all about?

"}]

fields.summary: Eschewing IaC, we look at the fast-enough and literally-step-by-step approach to telling a box in the cloud how to set up "all the things".

fields.top_content:
[{"id": "2feced3d-03b3-4be0-8041-03372f10a51f", "type": "rich_text", "value": "

About me

Welcome! I'm a software developer from Perth, Western Australia, who's mostly worked with full web stacks, but generally love all things Python, and many things DevOps.

This is my blog / personal website / little, decentralised, hand-rolled place on the internet where I can post and rant.

fields.summary: A step-by-step guide to deploying a Django app, for both development and production servers, to a single server in the cloud – using OpenTofu (a fork of Terraform), targeting DigitalOcean, utilising Just to manage the shell-scripting glue, and a hell of a lot of cloud-init.
fields.introduction:
[{"id": "8110632c-348c-4f52-98fa-bfd359249e99", "type": "rich_text", "value": "

The following is basically a walk-through of what I use to deploy this site. The vast majority of configuration is shared between between development, staging, test & production environments, with features toggled and controlled entirely though settings files & environment variables.

This site's code is open source, MIT-licensed and publicly available on GitHub, in case you want to see what I've been doing with it lately, or dig deeper into the code snippets offered below \u2013\u00a0but I'll try to keep this article as a \"live document\", and update it when anything significant changes.

The stack, or In Praise of Simplicity

Just

I use Just as a command runner, with one very big Justfile, and I can't recommend it highly enough. Shell scripts are alive and well [okay, well, as well as they've ever been] as the glue that holds all of \"computing\" and \"the internet\" together, whether you like it or not. Probably not.

Embracing Just amalgamates the dozens-to-hundreds of shell scripts any real project needs into a nice, sensible, single source. But if you're not into it or can't install it on that locked-down corporate server for some reason, the code inside my Justfile recipes is more-or-less POSIX-compliant shell script; you might just have to manage their yourself.

OpenTofu

Hopefully you're familiar with Terraform? After HashiCorp changed it to use a Business Source License (BSL), it was forked into OpenTofu, which aims to be backwards compatible and retain feature parity. At least for small use-cases such as the one here you can basically just type tofu instead of terraform. Or you could just use Terraform. Either way, \"tofu\" requires 5 fewer key-strokes.

cloud-init

Don't get me wrong; I love Infrastructure as Code (aka Iac); I've invested countless hours getting to grips with Salt in my spare time, and working with Puppet professionally. But when I wanted to start deploying development servers as easily and cheaply as possible\u00a0I started with a cloud-init script, because even if I wanted to go full-on IaC later, that provided the quickest way to iterate and actually make sure everything was going where it was meant to be.

And it turned out the time-to-deployment was so low (roughly 5 minutes), that it just hasn't been worth re-implementing everything you're about to see before you in higher-level abstractions.

"}]

About me

Welcome! I'm a software developer from Perth, Western Australia, who's mostly worked with full web stacks, but generally love all things Python, and many things DevOps.

This is my blog / personal website / little, decentralised, hand-rolled place on the internet where I can post and rant.

content.search_description: I'm a software developer from Perth, Australia, who loves most things Python. This is my little hand-crafted blog-cum-personal website-cum-little decentralised rant-hole on the internet.

content.title: Just using a Justfile
content.content:
[{"type": "rich_text", "value": "

Just is basically a command-runner, and a great blessing in my life. What have I done to \"just run commands\" in the past? I took a relatively standard-looking journey through the problem of \"running stuff\", which vaguely went:

  • Excessive use of man pages to remember arguments and flags
  • Abusive grepping of a shell's history to see what I'd done before
  • A Constant addition of aliases and functions to my shell via startup files
  • Pipenv [scripts], npm \"scripts\", other and other tool-spcific stuff
  • Make? CMake?!
  • Maybe just a bunch of .sh files under a scripts/ directory?
", "id": "cb48d52a-4faf-4e72-8c66-a44a91f1d564"}]
content.summary: Just is basically a command-runner. After decades of using other standard (but in retrospect ad-hoc methods), I've settled comfortably into writing just one Justfile, at the root of any given project, for the vast majority of "shell-scripty" stuff (aka the glue) required to get anything useful done.
content.tagline: Just is a beautiful solution to the problems lurking within the fraught problem-realm known to computer scientists as "running stuff"

fields.object_str: So I decided to start a blog

content.title: So I decided to start a blog
content.content:
[{"type": "rich_text", "value": "

Actually I decided to start a blog sometime late in the 20th century. And here it is! First I spend 2.5 decades as a web developer, working out what I need to know, and then finally found the time. This whole dammed \"web\" thing kept evolving and moving the goal posts, ya know?

Why am I here?

Many reasons.

  • I'm always learning new things, and spending all my time split between official documentation, books, ChatGPT, and StackOverflow, because there are no good tutorials or guides anywhere on the internet (that I can find), and I'm driven to close those gaps
  • Having your very own web presence felt like a cool idea to me in 1997, and I never lost that feeling. Skip to today, with centralised social media hastening the downfall of civilisation, it's not just cool it's literally revolutionary!
  • To earn a modicum of credibility as a developer/person/potential employee \u2013 and especially to feel confident calling myself a \"full stack\" developer \u2013 writing a front-end, a back-end, a DevOps pipeline, running it all in production yourself feels good
  • Now I have one repository that's also a rapid-development platform, which I can keep up-to-date with tooling, where I can experiment with whatever I want while not having to worry about bootstrapping new projects all the time\u00a0\u2013\u00a0\"feature\" branches, ftw!

What do I plan to write about?

Mostly I'm planning on writing up technical guides, recipes, tutorials, and what-have-yous, just based on whatever I've been learning or working with lately \u2013 but only when there isn't already a wealth of Googleable stuff out there already.

But this is my blog, and I'll be dammed if I'm going to hold myself back from the temptation to opine about whatever's going on in the world or my life. Maybe reviews of books and movies? I just like writing! You won't find a skerrick of \"AI generated\" content here.

What is it made of?

I took the best damn CMS framework in the world (Wagtail), written on top of the best dammed web framework in the world (Django), and wrote a CMS & blog application generic enough that I eventually split it out into a package called Picata. The goal is to develop Picata into a CMS solution others might find useful, since as wonderful as Wagtail is it does require weeks-to-months of full-stack developer time to turn it into a nice and working website, the the offerings for pre-built solutions are currently scarce.

You'll find more details between the Picata docs and the repo for this site itself.

I learned a lot of interesting modern stuff along the way, but TailwindCSS deserves a special mention for all the front-end styling you see before you; I found it utterly game-changing when it comes to rapidly generating pretty, concise, responsive CSS. It even made it easy to write themes you can change between (with those buttons in the top-right corner), and I could still do it all in Sass! (Mmmm, semantic whitespace.)

Epilogue

I'm not exactly a heavy user of all the social sites linked to in the footer, but it seemed wise to reference my official accounts on my own website, as a guard against identity theft, and to help the SEO bots know who I am.

Anyway, I hope you enjoy my stuff!

", "id": "4eaf4b81-ac26-4ca8-9e51-d2624c9bc4ac"}]
content.summary: Wherein I try to explain/justify the countless hours I've poured into getting this personal website off the ground. Includes a short description of the journey and technology behind it, and describes the expectations I've set for myself at this very early stage.
content.tagline: "What the hell am I doing here?"
content.draft_title: So I decided to start a blog
content.search_description: Where I try to justify the countless hours I've poured into getting this personal website off the ground.

content.title: Django settings in 4 parts
content.content:
[{"type": "rich_text", "value": "

The basics

Your Django settings are conceptually fairly simple, and should be kept simple in practice. For most purposes it's generally best to just start with three modules under your (project).settings package…

  • base.py for the vast majority of defaults not affected by the environment
  • dev.py, importing everything from base.py and adding dev/debug settings
  • prod.py, importing everything from base.py and adding production settings

I'd also go so far as to argue that your concrete settings files are literally the only place in a codebase where it's acceptable to just "import star", though hopefully you're using Ruff or a similar linter, and at least acknowledge the potential folly with an ignore directive…

", "id": "5462860b-3278-4e40-bdc0-4d8a2d16d5ea"}, {"type": "code", "value": {"code": "from .base import * # noqa: F403", "language": "python"}, "id": "956e470b-4eb4-4f34-9839-d38f1d7047b4"}, {"type": "rich_text", "value": "

Something fishy going on

Some time into development, after naïvely adding a lot of "dev-mode-and-debugging" stuff to my dev.py, I noticed a few of things:

  • My dev servers (which were DigitalOcean droplets with 2cpus & 8 gigs of ram at the time) were running out of memory a lot more often than they should
  • runserver_pluswas taking ages to start serving pages
  • django-admin commands were taking unusually long to run
  • mypy was taking yonks to do its thing, and mypyd was the main process eating up all of my precious memory
", "id": "bc7bb96e-766e-4f2d-bfd2-5503f05e2ce6"}, {"type": "rich_text", "value": "

The diagnosis

So yes, the thing is, if your "dev settings" just turn everything on at the module level then all those things are going to be imported and run whenever any Django management command runs.

If you've moved at all beyond the basics, that might mean you're loading django-extensions and the Django Debug Toolbar into your code with every command, and if you've stepped into the wonderful world of static type-checking you might be letting django-stubs monkey-patch your code. (Or at least I was…)

But: I found I don't actually need django-extensions for anything at all besides runserver(_plus), and monkey-patching type-hints into Django is resource intensive, and only needed for mypy[d].

", "id": "1a850079-9156-4e4b-8ec7-46a75d51feb1"}, {"type": "rich_text", "value": "

The solutions

Conditional settings & discovering the execution context

Django doesn't provide an immediately obvious way for you to tell exactly what spawned the code that's currently being imported…

Your manage.py is a simple little file that generally remains untouched, and acts as the entry-point for the django-admin command (assuming you aren't already just running things with python manage.py) – but people can and do often augment it for their own purposes and this is an ideal time to add a couple of lines before that final execute_from_command_line(argv) call:

", "id": "67e42a76-b7d9-4831-bbbc-3ba28829d167"}, {"type": "code", "value": {"code": "if len(argv) >= 2: # noqa: PLR2004 environ.setdefault("DJANGO_MANAGEMENT_COMMAND", argv[1]) from django.core.management import execute_from_command_line execute_from_command_line(argv)", "language": "python"}, "id": "eefff5a9-072d-4441-97b7-b1539a202111"}, {"type": "rich_text", "value": "

And now you can selectively and exclusively import django-extensions and all the DJDT stuff when you know you're in a runserver or runserver_plus context with something like like this in your (project).settings.dev module:

", "id": "a5c6cf0d-2bf2-4a29-ae68-f066f94c5435"}, {"type": "code", "value": {"code": "if getenv("DJANGO_MANAGEMENT_COMMAND", "").startswith("runserver"): RUNSERVERPLUS_POLLER_RELOADER_TYPE = "watchdog" RUNSERVER_PLUS_EXCLUDE_PATTERNS = [ ".venv/*", ".vscode/*", "node_modules/*", "media/*", "src/migrations/*", "static/*", ] # Enable Django Debug Toolbar and runserver_plus INSTALLED_APPS += [ "debug_toolbar", "django_extensions", ] MIDDLEWARE = ["debug_toolbar.middleware.DebugToolbarMiddleware", *MIDDLEWARE]", "language": "python"}, "id": "7240bf41-70ec-479d-9b25-85b556113571"}, {"type": "rich_text", "value": "

(and yes there are a few hints for other optimisations you should consider if you haven't already, embedded in that block of code.)

", "id": "95e5f16f-08ba-4c17-9a22-74dd47e8aaa9"}, {"type": "rich_text", "value": "

Settings exclusive to mypy (or whatever the kids are typing-checking with these days)

This brings us to the "in 4 parts" bit of this post. I now have a forth settings module in the form of mypy.py which consists entirely of:

", "id": "fc562879-e5f4-4ba1-8652-15318e91b3d8"}, {"type": "code", "value": {"code": """"Django settings for the mypy type-checking daemon.""" import django_stubs_ext from .dev import * # noqa: F403 django_stubs_ext.monkeypatch()", "language": "python"}, "id": "f9d368d0-1254-4ba7-ba13-24d63bc9a7cd"}, {"type": "rich_text", "value": "

… and then we can ensure the heavy burden of monkey-patching Django with type-hinting stubs happens when (and only when) needed by adding adding to our pyproject.toml:

", "id": "856e31fe-697d-4b07-a4fd-8da214c55ff4"}, {"type": "code", "value": {"code": "[tool.django-stubs] django_settings_module = "(project).settings.mypy"", "language": "toml"}, "id": "2efa12b4-15bf-4775-b331-1ef58b13dee1"}, {"type": "rich_text", "value": "

– that means:

  1. any mypyd processes VS Code might launch if you've got an extension like matangover.mypy installed, and
  2. the mypy process itself, which is great to run as a pre-commit hook.
", "id": "7e354794-1415-4e6e-b049-79ffaac523a8"}, {"type": "rich_text", "value": "

The result…

  • runserver[_plus] need not waste your resources on loading Django stubs
  • mypy[d] won't be wasting cycles & memory on debug stuff meant only for you
  • All the other Django management commands aren't bogged down by your debugging code or monkey-patched type-hints

… and you can be happier, and iterate faster, on smaller development boxes. And isn't that what it's really all about?

", "id": "8ebf1316-b2c0-4e01-9c3d-96b6e017c8c4"}]
content.summary: Development server running out of memory? Or maybe your runserver process is taking forever to load, and other management commands take too long? Here are some optimisation tips I used to speed up – and slim down – every part of my Django development experience.
content.tagline: "Import only what you need to survive"

content.title: pre-commit, Python typing & virtual envs
content.content:
[{"type": "rich_text", "value": "

The pre-commit package is a great way to quickly get a repo running with lots of checks you might not have even thought about, and shouldn't have to spend time manually coding into hooks yourself. It's certainly helping keep my projects extra-squeaky-clean in a way that feeds back to my brain in the form of lots of little dopamine hits.

Check out the .pre-commit-config.yaml file behind this site's codebase to see what I'm actually using on it today.

My initial concern, though, was that pre-commit install does of course take over the pre-commit hooks for a repository, because it relies on its own .git/hooks/pre-commit executable script – and it wasn't immediately obvious how I could just add my own arbitrary checks.

TL;DR?

"Repository local hooks" are your friend.

", "id": "d5d4814d-5e7c-4898-a957-4d2d2b4570bb"}, {"type": "rich_text", "value": "

Invisible virtual environments

One slightly magical, opaque implementation detail about pre-commit is that every hook basically creates and runs in its own virtual environment. What that looks like depends on the "language" associated with the hook itself, and there are a couple of notable exceptions:

  • "script" hooks, for simple scripts used to validate files,
  • "system" hooks, which target system-level executables, and
  • Repository-local hooks, most useful when the hook itself depends on build artefacts in your project, or fairly "complete" virtual environments that you don't want to re-build just for that hook.

Additional dependencies

If a hook isn't working the way you'd expect, it may be due to the fact that the virtual environment its creating for itself doesn't have quite everything it needs to run – this is where the additional_dependencies lists come into your configuration. Most hook repositories seem pretty good about mentioning the kind of things you'll need to add here – for example I got my eslint hook running with just:

", "id": "82f192b3-96e5-4884-8dcd-c924fede42f3"}, {"type": "code", "value": {"code": "- repo: https://github.com/pre-commit/mirrors-eslint rev: "v9.18.0" hooks: - id: eslint name: Lint ECMAScript with eslint args: ["--config", "./eslint.config.mjs"] additional_dependencies: - eslint@9.16.0 - eslint-plugin-prettier@5.2.1 - eslint-plugin-tailwindcss@3.17.5 - eslint-plugin-react@7.37.2 - typescript-eslint@8.17.0", "language": "yaml"}, "id": "a56202e8-ddf7-4818-8f07-5bbfe8296190"}, {"type": "rich_text", "value": "

Static typing, and just using 'local'

It was only after spending some time trying to get mypy for pre-commit working that the penny really dropped for me, with regard to how much of a working virtualenv some things actually need. Calling mypy . was finally going smoothly, with no more configuration required than what was in my pyproject.toml:

", "id": "ef2f1470-5df1-4ed2-a772-ac4d5e0e25cf"}, {"type": "code", "value": {"code": "[tool.mypy] exclude = [ '^(.git|.pytest_cache|.ruff_cache|.venv)/.*', '^(build|dist|infra|lib|logs|media|node_modules|snapshots|static)/.*', ] mypy_path = "$MYPY_CONFIG_FILE_DIR/src" plugins = ["mypy_django_plugin.main"] ignore_missing_imports = true [tool.django-stubs] django_settings_module = "picata.settings.mypy"", "language": "toml"}, "id": "928d2402-6b63-4711-a7e4-d1c142548849"}, {"type": "rich_text", "value": "

… but the mypy pre-commit hook was complaining about one more required dependency after another, until I realise I realised I was about to completely re-create pretty much my entire Python virtual environment, invisibly, in the background, just for this hook to run.

And it's not like mypy was going to change anything, so the principle of isolating pre-commit hooks in their own virtual environments for safety (or whatever) reasons seemed moot. Surely there had to be a better way?

The better way

As you might have guessed by now, the better way came in the form of abandoning the mypy pre-commit hook package completely, just using repo: local, and telling pre-commit what it was I wanted it to run against my already-built virtual environment:

", "id": "7ad59cae-8632-4881-b5d8-e73e294ed238"}, {"type": "code", "value": {"code": "- repo: local hooks: - id: mypy name: Type-check Python with mypy language: python types: [python] entry: mypy args: ["--config-file=pyproject.toml"]", "language": "yaml"}, "id": "e2829a7f-fcb4-445d-84a4-5d2f0a082f2d"}, {"type": "rich_text", "value": "

So, yeah. For many pre-commit checks, it might be easier to not go looking for a third-party repository, and just call what you want, when you want, how you want.

", "id": "9810f7db-f8d5-49cb-9e85-6a6ce1955e6b"}, {"type": "code", "value": {"code": "❯ pre-commit run mypy --all-files Type-check Python with mypy..............Passed", "language": "bash"}, "id": "b5fa2420-a43c-445a-8706-7c3269a91772"}]
content.summary: The pre-commit package is a great way to quickly get a repo running with lots of pre-commit checks you shouldn't have to spend time coding into hooks yourself. But it uses virtual environments behind the scenes in an opaque way that comes with a caveat you should be mindful of.
content.tagline: How I learned to stop worrying and love `repo: local`

content.title: Deploying Django all at once
content.introduction:
[{"type": "rich_text", "value": "

The following is basically a walk-through of what I use to deploy this site. The vast majority of configuration is shared between between development, staging, test & production environments, with features toggled and controlled entirely though settings files & environment variables.

This site's code is open source, MIT-licensed and publicly available on GitHub, in case you want to see what I've been doing with it lately, or dig deeper into the code snippets offered below \u2013\u00a0but I'll try to keep this article as a \"live document\", and update it when anything significant changes.

The stack, or In Praise of Simplicity

Just

I use Just as a command runner, with one very big Justfile, and I can't recommend it highly enough. Shell scripts are alive and well [okay, well, as well as they've ever been] as the glue that holds all of \"computing\" and \"the internet\" together, whether you like it or not. Probably not.

Embracing Just amalgamates the dozens-to-hundreds of shell scripts any real project needs into a nice, sensible, single source. But if you're not into it or can't install it on that locked-down corporate server for some reason, the code inside my Justfile recipes is more-or-less POSIX-compliant shell script; you might just have to manage their yourself.

OpenTofu

Hopefully you're familiar with Terraform? After HashiCorp changed it to use a Business Source License (BSL), it was forked into OpenTofu, which aims to be backwards compatible and retain feature parity. At least for small use-cases such as the one here you can basically just type tofu instead of terraform. Or you could just use Terraform. Either way, \"tofu\" requires 5 fewer key-strokes.

cloud-init

Don't get me wrong; I love Infrastructure as Code (aka Iac); I've invested countless hours getting to grips with Salt in my spare time, and working with Puppet professionally. But when I wanted to start deploying development servers as easily and cheaply as possible\u00a0I started with a cloud-init script, because even if I wanted to go full-on IaC later, that provided the quickest way to iterate and actually make sure everything was going where it was meant to be.

And it turned out the time-to-deployment was so low (roughly 5 minutes), that it just hasn't been worth re-implementing everything you're about to see before you in higher-level abstractions.

", "id": "8110632c-348c-4f52-98fa-bfd359249e99"}]

content.title: Deploying Django all at once
content.summary: A step-by-step guide to deploying a Django app, for both development and production servers, to a single server in the cloud – using OpenTofu (a fork of Terraform), targeting DigitalOcean, utilising Just to manage the shell-scripting glue, and a hell of a lot of cloud-init.

[{"type": "rich_text", "value": "

Don't get me wrong; I love Infrastructure as Code (aka Iac); I've invested countless hours getting to grips with Salt in my spare time, and working with Puppet professionally. But when I wanted to start deploying development servers as easily and cheaply as possible\u00a0I started with a cloud-init script, because even if I wanted to go full-on IaC later, that provided the quickest way to iterate and actually make sure everything was going where it was meant to be.

And it turned out the time-to-deployment was so low (roughly 5 minutes), that it just hasn't been worth re-implementing everything you're about to see before you in higher-level abstractions.

content.title: The big cloud-init post
content.summary: Eschewing IaC, we look at the fast-enough and literally-step-by-step approach to telling a box in the cloud how to set up "all the things".
